CN.summary: Authorities have periodically relied on strict lockdown measures and mass testing in areas with suspected COVID-19 cases, since the outbreak was first detected in Wuhan, Hubei province in late 2019. Health screening and sanitary measures have since been implemented in transportation hubs and other urban areas with international borders also open to essential travellers from several countries. While a new wave of infections and related movement restrictions have been intermittently imposed in Beijing, Shanghai and other areas since early March, authorities claim the situation is under control, but there is a lack of credible information from the government, which makes it difficult to ascertain the true number of cases. Some of the country's Urban areas, including Shanghai, are imposing indefinite lockdown and city-wide testing following record-high outbreaks.

areaRestrictions.text:
Lockdowns are periodically imposed in areas with detected or suspected cases without much prior notice. Although not always immediately, these areas are designated as high- or medium risk areas depending on the number of new COVID-19 cases. Such lockdowns are in principle lifted after continuous days (about a week) of no new detection of COVID-19 cases, but it is up to the discretion of local authorities.

Shanghai: Lockdown measures, including the suspension of subway services, are ongoing and authorities have yet to specify when the measures will be lifted.

In lockdown areas, the public is reportedly not allowed to leave lockdown to procure food and other basic essentials without approval, and has to rely on authorities distributing such supplies at delivery points. Officials announced that courier services may resume in non-epidemic areas under strict health screening measures. Non-compliance or those found boycotting the lockdown measures are reportedly penalised; it was not clear what the exact penalties were.

On 1 May, authorities allowed residents to leave home for buying essentials in \'prevention\' areas, including Fengxian, Jinshan, Chongming, Qingpu, Songjiang and Putuo districts, where public transport and the use of private vehicles also gradually resumed. In \'closed\' and \'controlled\' areas, including Huangpu, Jing\'an, Xuhui, Changning, Hongkou, Yangpu, Baoshan, Minhang and Jiading 9, lockdown measures remain in effect.

From 16 May, some businesses, including supermarkets and pharmacies, have reopened with limits on business hours and capacity; customers must obtain approval to leave lockdown and travel on pre-determined routes to visit these businesses. Also, some public areas opened and bus services resumed in the Fengxian district.

Officials have implemented Preventive/Precautionary Zones, which allow limited movement within the designated zone. The area must not have an active case for the past two weeks to be designated as the zone. Around 7,000 localised areas have been designated under the zone. Workers of select “whitelisted” companies who tested negative for COVID-19 on a nucleic acid test were allowed to commute to work on predetermined routes.

Local authorities impose a \'closed-loop management\' system, which allows some companies to resume operations, provided that all workers sleep at or near the worksite.

The United States government ordered all non-emergency consular staff and their family members to leave Shanghai. The US Consulate in Shanghai remains operational.

Beijing: All residents and visitors on work purposes living in Beijing’s Chaoyang district have been ordered to get tested for COVID-19; authorities often periodically require mass testings across Beijing, especially in areas with confirmed or suspected COVID-19 cases. COVID-19 restrictions were reportedly tightened in areas east of Huanhuan, west of Xidawang Road, north of Huawei South Road and Songyu South Road, and south of Guangqu Road where residents were not allowed to leave their communities and non-essential businesses were closed. Large gatherings such as sports events and performances were suspended. Several areas in Beijing were upgraded to high- and medium-risk, including those in Chaoyang, Fangshan and Tongzhou districts. Authorities have shut down without notice more than 40 metro stations and at least 158 bus routes across Beijing, especially in the Chaoyang and Fangshan districts as part of the campaign against the spread of COVID-19. People were ordered to work from home in Chaoyang and Fangshan districts, while officials in several other areas also reportedly urged people to work remotely.

Zhengzhou, Henan province: Authorities announced that businesses were allowed to fully resume, and public transport resumed with QR code checks on the Zheng Haoban Apple or Android apps, temperature checks and a face mask mandate are in effect across non-lockdown areas.

Authorities lifted lockdown measures in parts of Erqi, Jinshui, Guancheng and Zhongyuan districts, as well as Zhongmu county, Dengfeng and Xingyang. However, localised lockdown measures are still in effect in areas that were not mentioned in this list, including Huiji district and Xinmi city.

Jinhua, Zhejiang province: Lockdown measures have been imposed across Loujia, Lianfeng, Zezhu, Honglu, Wangludang, Xiayang, Yicun and Shibai villages in Bailongqiao town, Xiayao village, and Linjiang and Zhachuan industrial parks among other areas in the Wucheng district.

Tangshan, Hebei province: COVID-19 related lockdown measures, including a stay-at-home order, movement restrictions requiring negative test results and the suspension of non-essential businesses, have been imposed across Laoting County until further notice, while lockdown measures were lifted in the Lubei district. Authorities did not specify whether or not the previously imposed lockdown measures in Lunan, Fengnan, Kaiping and Yutian districts were also lifted.

Langfang, Hebei province: Authorities maintained lockdown measures in the Xicheng district in Sanhe, including the Yanjiao High-tech Zone, as well as Yanjiao, Xinggong and Gaolou areas. Lockdown measures have been lifted in the east urban area, but restaurant dine-ins remained suspended, and entertainment venues remained closed to discourage traffic during the Labour Day holiday on 1 May.

Mass testing was held across all of Langfang’s Sanhe on 3 May. Authorities lifted the lockdown in Dongcheng district on the same day following the completion of mass testing. The lockdown in the Xishi district is still in effect until further notice.

Changchun, Jilin province: Gradual lifting of lockdown measures is underway as no new COVID-19 cases have been detected. Residents cannot take public transport among other self-health monitoring measures for seven days once the lockdown is lifted from their area. Dine-in services remain suspended while mass nucleic acid testing every three days is maintained in the main urban area including the Jiutai district.

Other areas

Residents of communities within areas of designated as high- and medium-risk areas cannot leave their localities or even their residential buildings, while those in low-risk areas can leave and re-enter their areas unless told otherwise by authorities. Movements of residents and vehicles on roads have not been allowed in some areas on lockdown. Security forces enforce lockdown measures.

High- or medium-risk areas have been designated in the following cities.

Direct-administered municipalities: [high and medium] Beijing, [medium] Shanghai

Hebei province: [medium] Changde

Liaoning province: [medium] Dandong and Yingkou

Heilongjiang province: [medium] Harbin

Guangdong province: [medium] Zhanjiang

Sichuan province: [medium] Guang\'an

The updated list of specific high- and medium-risk areas can be found here.

Flights, intercity transport and public transit are regularly suspended in areas on lockdown or with suspected cases.

All provinces advised against non-essential inter-regional travel, particularly to and from cities with high- or medium-risk areas; cross-city buses, taxis and ride-sharing services in those areas were suspended. The updated list of high- and medium-risk areas can be found here.

Check here for updated information on domestic travel restrictions and destination municipalities\' most updated COVID-19 related policies.

Group and package (air ticket + hotel) tours to/from province-level divisions (provinces, direct-administered municipalities, autonomous regions and special administrative regions) with high-risk areas were prohibited.

Only travellers with a green health code, issued to those who were not in any medium- or high-risk areas in the preceding 14 days, with a negative nucleic acid test result from within 48 hours prior to departure have been permitted entry. These travellers must test again upon arrival. Arrivals from high-risk areas must quarantine for 14 days at a designated government facility and a further seven days of health monitoring, while those from medium-risk areas must self-quarantine for 14 days and a further seven days of health monitoring.

Beijing: Those who visited regions with more than one locally confirmed case within 14 days are banned from entry, while those who visited regions with international ports of entry are advised to not enter Beijing. Arrivals at a port of entry outside of Beijing must quarantine at a government-designated facility for 14 days to be allowed entry into Beijing.

A negative nucleic acid test no older than 48 hours for COVID-19 is required to enter Beijing.

Shanghai: Residents were urged to avoid outbound travel. Intercity bus service is suspended.

A negative nucleic acid test no older than 48 hours for COVID-19 is required to enter or leave Shanghai.

Some domestic flights, both inbound and outbound, resumed at Shanghai Pudong International Airport (PVG/ZSPD). Further flights are planned to gradually resume.

Guangzhou, Guangdong province: Only citizens with essential reasons and who carry a negative nucleic acid test result taken within 48 hours before departure are allowed to exit Guangzhou.

Jianxi province: Those returning to Jianxi province and who have a travel history in designated domestic high-risk areas within the 14 days before departure must self-isolate for seven days at a government-designated facility. These travellers must then undergo a seven-day home health monitoring.

Xinyang\'s Cushi County, Henan province: Inbound travellers must have a negative test certificate no older than 48 hours as well as green health and itinerary codes to enter.

Public gatherings are limited to 50 people in areas with a high risk of transmission rates.

Beijing: A negative result of a COVID-19 test taken within the past 48 hours is required to enter public venues and use public transport.

Wuhan, Hubei province: On 8 April 2020, authorities formally lifted a 76-day lockdown on Wuhan, the epicentre of the outbreak, allowing healthy residents and visitors to leave the city. Residents living in and outside Wuhan are allowed to travel into the city to resume work if they have a green health code issued by the government and normal body temperature. Residents across Hubei are still urged to avoid large gatherings and maintain hygiene and distancing measures while many businesses have reopened.

Hangzhou, Zhejiang province: Residents must take a nucleic acid test at least once every 48 hours in Hangzhou.

Xinyang's Cushi County, Henan province: Entertainment venues are closed, capacity is limited to 50 percent in public places, a two-metre social distancing rule and a face mask mandate are in effect, and inbound travellers must have a negative test certificate no older than 48 hours as well as green health and itinerary codes to enter.

Covid Pass is required for some domestic activities: Domestic travellers with a “green” health code have been allowed on trains without negative COVID-19 nucleic acid test certificates in most areas. Trains arriving at Beijing, as well as those departing from Harbin in Heilongjiang province still require a negative COVID-19 test result issued within 48 hours prior to departure along with a green health code to board. Some city and province level municipalities require their own tracing apps to be installed in addition to apps necessary for generating QR health codes.

From 30 April, residents in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province must show a nucleic acid test result issued within 48 hours to access public venues and use public transport. Similar measures are in place in eligible areas of Shanghai. A health code check is required for all individuals to gain entry into retail stores and supermarkets in Shanghai.

Covid Pass availability: A “green” health code can be obtained through government, WeChat or Alipay apps.

transportation.text:
Authorities have required travellers from some countries to only arrive on direct flights (no connecting flights in a third country). Check departure country's Chinese Embassy for updates.

Many international airlines have reduced commercial flights to and from China. Chinese officials previously requested airlines to operate only one flight per week to an international destination, mostly to repatriate foreign nationals and bring in essential personnel. Airlines must limit passenger load on flights at 75 percent. However, some international flights without any passenger who tested positive for COVID-19 for three weeks have been exempt from this policy.

Airlines have been allowed to choose a city with one or more airports that are capable of accommodating international passenger flights and operate one international flight per week.

Aviation authorities have maintained that if five or more COVID-19 cases are confirmed among airline passengers after arriving on an international commercial flight, the carrier will be barred from operating flights to and from China for two weeks; if the number of cases reaches 10 or more, a four-week ban will be imposed.

Authorities cancelled all of Shandong Airline's SC4708 flights connecting Incheon International Airport (ICN/RKSI) serving Seoul in South Korea with Yantai Penglai International Airport (YNT/ZSYT) in Shandong province.

Authorities also cancelled Scoot's TR116 and TR117 flights between Zhengzhou Xinzheng International Airport (CGO/ZHCC) in Henan province and Singapore’s Changi Airport (SIN/WSSS).

The government banned all flights to and from the United Kingdom, and some flights from Algeria and Myanmar.

International flights through Beijing Daxing Airport (PKX/ZBAD) and Shenyang Taoxian International Airport (SHE/ZYTX) in Liaoning province have been suspended.

declarationDocuments.text:
Health document
All incoming travellers must fill out an online health declaration form before travel and procure a QR code.

Travel (PLF) document
Non-Chinese nationals must obtain a health code with a "HDC" mark through the online Health Declaration Certificate by uploading all necessary documents, including negative test results for COVID-19, before 09:00 departure country time on the day before departure. The required documents can differ depending on the location of departure; check the Chinese embassy or consulate responsible for the departure location for the most up to date document requirements. Travellers who recieved vaccination against COVID-19 must wait at least 14 days after their final dose before applying for a health code.

Vaccinated travellers must complete and upload their Letter of Commitment on COVID-19 Vaccination as well as a vaccination certificate when obtaining a health code.

Travel (PLF) document
Chinese Nationals must obtain a health code with a "HS" mark through the WeChat app's Prevention Health Code International Version mini-program by uploading all necessary documents, including negative test results for COVID-19, before 09:00 departure country time on the day before departure. The required documents can differ depending on the location of departure; check the Chinese embassy or consulate responsible for the departure location for the most up to date document requirements.

Vaccinated travellers must complete and upload their Letter of Commitment on COVID-19 Vaccination as well as a vaccination certificate when obtaining a health code.

entry.text:
Chinese officials discourage any non-urgent or non-essential travel to China from any country, but there are no specific bans on inbound travel so long as the traveller obtains a visa and meet all COVID-19 related entry requirements as instructed by the Chinese Embassy or consulates in the departure country. However, visas are approved on a case-by-case basis at the discretion of Chinese officials.

Foreign travellers with valid residency permits for work, personal affairs or family reunification can enter, while diplomats, travellers on essential official business and "C" visa holders in international transportation services may enter on a case by case basis. Eligible visa holders whose visas expired after 28 March 2020 may apply for a visa renewal at a Chinese Embassy or Consulate.

Requirements for entry vary depending on the traveller\'s country of departure, including vaccination, testing and pre-departure quarantine; All travellers are required to obtain a Health Code from the departure country\'s Chinese Embassy or consulates to board China-bound flights. These requirements are updated on each Chinese Embassy\'s website.

Travellers entering on transit flights are only allowed entry into China if there are no direct flights to China from their initial departure countries. Such travellers are subject to health monitoring, COVID-19 testing requirements and other requirements set by the Chinese embassies or consulates in transit countries before being issued a Health Code needed for boarding China-bound flights.

Travellers who were previously infected with COVID-19 are permitted to enter only after three months of rehabilitation. After rehabilitation, these travellers must provide a chest X-ray three months before flight check-in (using a conventional X-ray or CT scan confirming the absence of pathologies in the lungs or a cure from COVID-19), and two negative PCR test results after the chest x-ray with at least a 24-hour interval between the two tests, to the Chinese Embassy in the departure country within 72 hours of the second PCR test to be permitted entry. Travellers must also self-isolate after the second PCR test until their date of departure. Further testing and other requirements can apply as directed by the Chinese Embassy/Consulate of the departure country. Some Chinese embassies, including the one in Malaysia, require previously infected travellers to contact them for information on additional requirements.

Travellers who are close contacts or have COVID-19 symptoms must undergo 14 days of isolation and health monitoring with nucleic acid tests conducted on days one, four and seven of isolation. Entry is only allowed for those who test negative on all tests.

Previously suspended land crossing between Dongxing in Guangxi Zhuang autonomous region and Móng Cái in Quảng Ninh province of Vietnam reopened since 10 January. Health screening controls remain in place at airports, major highways, waterways and railway stations.

The Torugart border crossing along the China-Kyrgyzstan border is open to allow the movement of goods.

The Erenhot border trading zone located between China’s Erenhot (Inner Mongolia autonomous region) and Mongolia’s Zamiin-Uud (Dornogovi province) has been reopened, mostly for cross-border trade and logistics operators.

Officials restricted the Jiegao Bridge at the international border crossing with Myanmar in Ruili, Yunnan province, on 30 March 2021 after the Jiegao area was designated as a COVID-19 high-risk area. The area is now a low-risk area, but authorities were yet to clarify whether or not the bridge was open for crossing.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Most passengers arriving by air must possess negative nucleic acid test or IgM antibody test certificates for COVID-19, issued by facilities recognised by Chinese embassies prior to boarding flights (usually within 24 hours prior to departure). The test results must then be uploaded to the online Health Declaration Certificate\xa0for non-Chinese nationals and the WeChat app's Prevention Health Code International Version mini-program for Chinese nationals to obtain a health code necessary for boarding China-bound flights. Check the departure country's Chinese Embassy/Consulate websites (usually the Consular section's Notices) for updated pre-departure testing requirements.

Travellers who tested positive for COVID-19 on an IgM antibody test against S protein due to being recently vaccinated for COVID-19 have still been able to apply for the online health code necessary for entry as long as they waited for 14 days after receiving all necessary vaccine doses, and upload a report of negative IgM antibody test result against N protein, a Letter of Commitment on COVID-19 Vaccination and a vaccination certificate. Check departure countries' Chinese Embassy websites for relevant documents.

NORTH AMERICA

The United States

All travellers departing from the United States, including those transiting, must have a negative result of a COVID-19 RT-PCR test taken seven days before departure and test negative on additional tests within 24 hours before departure as well as an antigen test within 12 hours before departure at a Chinese Embassy/Consulate approved testing facilities, including those of Ayass Bioscience and Realtime Laboratories. The type and number of additional tests depend on one’s vaccination status. Those fully vaccinated with an inactivated vaccine must take two RT-PCR tests from two different testing sites within 24 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines, unvaccinated or partially vaccinated must take a second RT-PCR test, an S protein IgM antibody test and an N protein IgM antibody test. There are direct flights to China departing from Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, New York, Detroit and Dallas. Check here for the Chinese Embassy/Consulates responsible for each departure location and further details.

Canada

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test seven days before departure and an antigen test 12 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take a second nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure and a third one 24 hours before departure, while others must take a serum antibody test within 48 hours before departure and a second nucleic acid test 24 hours before departure. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

EUROPE

The United Kingdom

Travellers departing from the United Kingdom (UK) must take their first nucleic acid test at a legally registered clinic seven days before departure, followed by a "double test" including a nucleic acid test and an IgM antibody test either on the day of or two natural days before departure at institutions designated by the Chinese Embassy; the "double test" must be carried out at a facility separate from where the first test was taken. Those who test positive on their antibody test must receive a negative result on a separate IgM antibody N protein test within 48 hours before departure; the separate N protein test does not have to be taken at the same facility where the "double test" was taken. Information on facilities where N protein tests can be taken can be found here.

Germany

Fully vaccinated travellers must take a nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure and another one 24 hours before departure at separate facilities, while not fully vaccinated travellers must take a serum IgM antibody test within 48 hours before departure and a nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure at separate facilities; all travellers must also take an antigen test 12 hours before departure. All tests must be taken at a formal testing facility within one consular area; there is no approved list of testing facilities by the Chinese Embassy in Germany. Consular districts of\xa0Berlin, Brandenburg, May, Saxony, Saxony and Thuringia constitute the Berlin Embassy consular area,\xa0Hamburg, Bremen, Lower Saxony and Schleswig-Holstein the\xa0Hamburg Consulate General consular area, Bavaria the\xa0Munich\xa0Consulate General consular area,\xa0Hesse,\xa0Rhineland-Palatinate,\xa0Baden-Württemberg and Saarland the\xa0Frankfurt\xa0Consulate General consular area, and\xa0North Rhine-Westphalia the\xa0Dusseldorf Consulate General consular area.

France

Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take two nucleic acid tests, while others must take an IgM antibody test and a nucleic acid test at one of the testing institutions approved by the Chinese Embassy in France, the list of which can be found here. The required time for testing differs depending on flights; travellers on flights CA934, MU570, AF 198 and AF382 must test on the morning of their departure days, while those on CZ348 must test between 14:00 and 17:00 on Wednesdays; all tests are valid for 12 hours. Transit travellers must take two nucleic acid tests, but at the designated agency in the transit area of Paris Charles de Gaulle Airport (CDG/LFPG).

Italy

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test seven days before departure, a second nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure and a third one 24 hours before departure at separate facilities, and an antigen test 12 hours before departure. All tests must be carried out at facilities approved by the Chinese Embassy in Italy.

Spain

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test seven days before departure and an antigen test 12 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must then take a second nucleic acid test 48 hours before departure and a third one 24 hours before departure at separate facilities, while others must take an IgM antibody test (test against N protein for those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines) within 48 hours before departure and a second nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure at separate facilities. A list of approved testing facilities can be found here.

ASIA PACIFIC

Australia

All travellers must take a PCR test seven days before departure, another PCR test 24 hours before departure and an antigen test on the day of departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must additionally take a PCR test within 48 hours before departure, while others must take an IgM antibody test (N protein antibody test for those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines) within 48 hours before departure. Unless for a special reason, including not being a resident of cities with direct flights to China, all tests must be conducted at the city of departure.

New Zealand

Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must\xa0have negative results of two nucleic acid tests, while others must\xa0have those of an IgM antibody test for N protein and a nucleic acid test, taken after 15:00 local time on the day before departure. All travellers must also have a negative result of a supervised antigen test taken after 09:00 New Zealand time on the day of departure. All results must be submitted to\xa0the review platform of the Chinese Embassy or Consulate in New Zealand.

Japan

All travellers must take a PCR test seven days before departure, followed by two additional PCR tests at least 24 hours apart within 72 hours before departure. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

South Korea

All travellers must take a PCR test seven days before departure. They must also take another PCR test within 12 hours before departure if their departure time is after 13:00; if their departure time is at or before 13:00, travellers must take the additional PCR test 24 hours before departure and an antigen test 12 hours before. Furthermore, travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take two PCR tests within 48 hours before departure, while others must take an IgM antibody test (an N protein antibody test for those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines) and a PCR test within 48 hours before departure. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

Singapore

Most travellers must take a nucleic acid test 24 hours before departure; those six years old and above must also take an antigen test at the Singapore Changi Airport (SIN/WSSS) testing point (Changi Testing Facility, Terminal 3 Level 1, Coach Stand) between two-six hours before departure on the day of flight check-in (reservations must be made at least one day in advance). Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take another nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure, while others must take an IgM antibody test (N protein antibody test for those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines) 48 hours before departure. The 48 hours before departure test and the 24 hours before departure test must be conducted at separate facilities; one of the tests must be taken at a partner clinic of Raffles Medical Group or Parkway Medical Group.

Travellers on temporary or charter flights to China must take a PCR test on the seventh day before departure, then undergo seven days of self-isolation and health monitoring and take a second PCR test on the second day before departure and a third PCR test within 12 hours before departure.

Malaysia

All travellers must take an RT-PCR test seven days before departure, another RT-PCR test within 24 hours before departure and an airline arranged antigen test within 12 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take an additional nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure, while others must take an antibody test (N protein IgM antibody test for those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines) within 24 hours before departure. All RT-PCR and antibody tests taken within 24 hours before departure must be taken at different facilities. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

Indonesia

All travellers must be tested negative for COVID-19 on a nucleic acid test before entering seven days of pre-departure isolation implemented by airlines. Furthermore,\xa0travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take two nucleic acid tests within 24 hours before departure, while others must take a serum IgM antibody test (N protein antibody test for those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines) and a nucleic acid test at designated hospitals within 24 hours before departure. All travellers must also take an airline arranged antigen test within 12 hours before departure. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

Thailand

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test seven days before departure, another nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure and an antigen test within 12 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must additionally take a nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure, while others must take an IgM test (those vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines must take an N protein IgM test) and an IgG antibody test within 24 hours before departure. All nucleic acid and antibody tests within 48 hours before departure must be conducted at different facilities. A list of approved facilities can be found here.

Travellers transiting in Thailand must\xa0stay in Thailand for at least 28 days, and take a COVID-19 nucleic acid test seven days, 72 hours and 48 hours before departure to obtain a Health Code required for entry into China.

Vietnam

Fully vaccinated travellers must take two nucleic acid tests within 48 hours before departure; the two tests must be taken at different test sites and be taken more than 24 hours apart from each other. All others must take a nucleic acid test and a serum IgM antibody test within 24 hours before departure. All of these tests must be taken within the Chinese Embassy's consular area of the departure city. Additionally, all travellers must take an antigen test within 12 hours before departure. A list of approved testing facilities can be found here.

Cambodia

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test 14 days before departure, a second nucleic acid test three days before departure, two additional nucleic acid tests using different test types for different samples from left and right nostrils as well as an antibody test within 24 hours before departure, and an antigen test within 12 hours before departure. The first test must be taken at the National Institute of Public Health, while all other tests must be taken at the Royal Military Hospital of Cambodia.

The Philippines

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test seven days before departure, another nucleic acid test 24 hours before departure and an antigen test 12 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must additionally take a nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure, while others must take a serum IgM antibody test within 24 hours before departure; nucleic acid tests within 48 hours before departure must be taken at different facilities, while the antibody test can be taken at the same facility as the nucleic acid test. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

East Timor

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure and an antigen test within 12 hours before departure. Fully vaccinated travellers must take an additional nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure, while others must additionally take an IgM antibody test within 24 hours before departure. All tests must be taken at approved facilities, which can be found here.

India

All travellers must take an RT-PCR test 14 days before departure, a second RT-PCR test within 72 hours before departure and another RT-PCR test within 12 hours before departure. Fully vaccinated travellers must take an additional RT-PCR test within 48 hours before departure, while others must take an IgM antibody test instead within 47 hours before departure. The last two RT-PCR tests must be taken at least 24 hours apart from each other. All tests must be taken at a testing institution authorized by the Indian Council of Medical Research.

Pakistan

All travellers departing from Islamabad must take a PCR test seven days before departure, two further PCR tests at different facilities within 24 hours before departure and another PCR test within 12 hours before departure. Travellers not fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must additionally take two IgM antibody tests at different facilities. Approved testing facilities can be found here.

Travellers departing from Karachi must take a PCR test at a designated institution between 21 and 28 days before departure and again seven days prior to departure. A "double-test" for COVID-19 is also required within 24 hours before departure as well as a rapid antigen test within 12 hours prior to departure.

Updates for travellers departing from Islamabad can be found here, and those departing Karachi here.

Sri Lanka

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test 14 days before departure, a second nucleic acid test within 72 hours before departure and an antigen test 12 hours before departure. Travellers fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines must take two additional nucleic acid tests at different facilities (one must be at Lanka Hospital with Chinese equipment) with one taken within 24 hours before departure, while others must take an IgM antibody test within 48 hours before departure and a third nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure at the Lanka Hospital using a different test type or a facility different from where the second nucleic acid test was taken. The list of approved testing facilities can be found here.

Nepal

All travellers must take a nucleic acid test 14 days before departure, a second nucleic acid test within 72 hours before departure and an antigen test 12 hours before departure. Fully vaccinated travellers must take a third nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure and a fourth one within 24 hours before departure; the third and fourth tests must be taken at different facilities. Not fully vaccinated travellers must take an IgM antibody test and a third nucleic acid test within 24 hours before departure; the third nucleic acid test must be taken at a facility different from where the second test was taken. Information on approved testing facilities can be found here.

Papua New Guinea

Travellers who are fully vaccinated with inactivated vaccines, including Sinopharm, must hold two negative PCR test results, while those fully vaccinated with non-inactivated vaccines must hold negative certificates of a PCR test and a serum IgM antibody test against N protien; the tests must all be taken within 48 hours before departure, with the last test taken within 24 hours before departure. The two tests must be taken at two different hospitals recognised by the Chinese embassy listed here. However, all returnees must hold a negative result of an antigen test taken within two-four hours before departure. Those who tested positive must present two negative nucleic acid test results (submit to consulate_png@mfa.gov.cn) and undergo a 14-day self-isolation prior to taking another two antibody and antigen test 48 hours before departure.

French Polynesia

Those fully vaccinated with activated vaccines (Pfizer, Janssen, etc.) or those unvaccinated must be tested with an antibody test 48 hours before departure and another antigen or nucleic acid test within 12 hours prior to departure. While those who received inactivated vaccine (also including those who received an activated booster dose) must be tested with a nucleic acid test within 48 hours before departure (the test should have an interval of 24 hours and the second test should be taken within 12 hours before departure). Check here for the complete testing requirements and healthcare facilities recognised by the Chinese embassy.

SUB SAHARA AFRICA

South Africa

Most travellers must undergo a nasopharyngeal swab nucleic acid test on the 14th day before departure and a second test on the seventh day before departure at a test site different from where the first test was taken; all tests must be taken at one of Pathcare, Ampath or Lancet facilities. Those undergoing centralised pre-departure quarantine at Southern Sun O.R. Tambo International Airport Hotel in Johannesburg, including not fully vaccinated travellers, must instead take a serum IgM antibody test on the second day before departure and a nucleig acid test on the day of departure.

All travellers must have a negative COVID-19 test certificate issued within 72 hours prior to departure. Test results must be uploaded to the online Health Declaration Certificate to receive clearance for boarding China-bound flights. Only foreign nationals with inoculation certificates for COVID-19 vaccines produced in China have been exempted from submission requirements of negative COVID-19 nucleic acid test results and Health and Travel Record Declaration Forms for visa applications when entering for work-related purposes from Hong Kong.

A negative result of a COVID-19 nucleic acid test taken within 48 hours before departure is necessary for travellers to enter Beijing from Macau.

A negative result of a COVID-19 nucleic acid test taken within seven days before departure is necessary for travellers to enter Guangdong province via land checkpoints from Macau.

Upon arrival

Travellers have been tested upon arrival at Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, Shenzen, Qingdao, Hangzhou and Guangzhou airports before proceeding to quarantine. Similar upon arrival testings are possible at other airports. Fully vaccinated travellers from Hong Kong have also been tested upon arrival.

After arrival

Every foreign country is considered a COVID-19 high-risk area, and thus all international arrivals are subject to after arrival COVID-19 testing - mostly during their isolation period. The exact number of tests arrivals need to take as well as where and when these tests need to be taken can differ between each municipality and such policies can change depending on the municipalities' epidemiological situation. Each municipality's most up to date policies can be found here.

All arrivals in Beijing and Fujian province's Xiamen must test for COVID-19. Arrivals in Shanghai must take six COVID-19 PCR tests, those arriving in Tianjin four times each week during their quarantine and health monitoring periods, Travellers transiting in Sichuan province's Chengdu must take a nucleic acid test before being allowed to continue their travel. Similar after arrival testing requirements are likely at other ports of entry.

Guangdong province: International travellers arriving in Guangzhou must take multiple tests for COVID-19 during quarantine.

Shenyang in Liaoning province: International arrivals must test for COVID-19 on days 1, 4, 7, 14, 21 and 28 of quarantine.

Sichuan province: Arrivals must test for COVID-19 on days one, four, seven, 10 and 14 of quarantine.

Fully vaccinated travellers from Hong Kong have been tested on day 14 of quarantine.
diseaseTesting.when: Before travel, Upon arrival, After arrival

tracingApplication.text: WeChat and Alipay, two most widely-used mobile apps for financial transactions across China, also generate QR health codes for contact tracing; these codes have to be scanned by all individuals when entering any public area. Some city and province level municipalities require their own tracing apps to be installed in addition to apps necessary for generating QR health codes.

quarantineModality.text:
Most travellers arriving from abroad are required to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival at a government-approved facility or hotel at the travellers' own expense, followed by further seven days of home or facility isolation, but local quarantine requirements can differ between cities and change with little prior notice. The most up to date official quarantine policy changes for each municipality can be found through here. Some localities implementing home isolations after centralised quarantine have allowed transiting travellers to undergo centralised quarantine at the port of entry and complete the home isolation at their final destinations.

Beijing: International arrivals must quarantine at a government-designated facility for 10 days, then at home for a further seven days; those without a residence or whose final destination is outside of Beijing must only quarantine at a government-designated facility for 14 days.

Shanghai as well as Jiangsu, Zhejiang and Anhui provinces: All arrivals must quarantine at government-designated facilities for 14 days upon arrival, then undergo seven days of health monitoring at home or a designated facility, during which travellers can only leave for essentail purposes with approval from authorities.

Guangdong province: Arrivals in Shenzhen and Guangzhou must undergo 14 days of hotel quarantine followed by seven days of home quarantine. Arrivals in Guangzhou must also monitor their health for seven days after their home quarantine. A quarantine-free travel scheme for travellers from Macau to Guangdong province at the Zhuhai-Macau border crossing was suspended. Nevertheless, travellers from Macau with negative results of COVID-19 nucleic acid test taken within seven days prior to departure who were not in other countries in the prior 14 days have been allowed quarantine free entry through Zhuhai border crossings.

Chengdu, Sichuan province: All arrivals must quarantine at a government-designated facility, including hotels, at their own cost for 14 days, followed by seven days of home quarantine; those without a fixed residence in Chengdu must only quarantine at a government-designated facility for 21 days. Arrivals, whose final destination is not Chengdu, are allowed to continue their travel after just the 14-day quarantine at a government-designated facility.

Xiamen, Fujian province: Arrivals must quarantine at a government-designated facility for 10 days, followed by health monitoring at home for seven days. Those whose final destination is not Xiamen must stay in the government-designated quarantine area for four more days after their 10-day quarantine to be allowed to travel out of Xiamen.

mask.text: Individuals who are ill or members of a health risk group have to wear face masks in crowded public venues. Face mask mandates are frequently imposed in areas with new COVID-19 cases and lifted after around 14 days of no new cases. Have masks at hand in the event they are mandated.

exit.text:
All outgoing travellers must fill out an online health declaration form before travel and procure a QR code.

Authorities urged Chinese nationals against non-essential outbound international travel and announced stricter reviews for passport issuance as well as travel documents.

Air travellers departing from Chengdu, Sichuan province, must provide an electric or paper negative nucleic acid test result of a COVID-19 test taken within 48 hours before departure.

Chinese nationals on non-essential business are not allowed to exit through land border crossings at Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous region and Torugart border crossing with Kyrgyzstan. Residents require permission from government to obtain passports for leaving the country.

otherRestriction.text:
Pre-departure quarantine for select countries

Travellers arriving from high-risk COVID-19 countries, including Malaysia and Indonesia as well as Chinese returnees from China-funded institutions and projects in Egypt, Vietnam and South Africa must self-quarantine for 21 days prior to departure. Travellers from South Africa and Pakistan have been eligible for shorter 14 days of pre-departure self-quarantine.

Travellers from South Africa opt for a shoter 5-day and 4-night pre-departure quarantine centralised pre-departure quarantine at the Southern Sun O.R. Tambo International Airport Hotel in Johannesburg. Those with close contact history and suspected symptoms of COVID-19 must self-isolate for 14 days and undergo nucleic acid tests for COVID-19 on the 1st, 4th and 7th day of isolation and complete the Personal Health Monitoring Form. The test results and the Personal Health Monitoring Form must be sent to the Chinese Embassy or Consulates in Durban, Cape Town or Johannesburg to be approved for pre-departure testing and quarantine procedures.

Pre-departure quarantine requirements can be imposed with little prior notice. Contact the departure countries\' Chinese Embassies in advance for details and updates.

Egypt, Thailand, Indonesia, Spain, Italy and the United Kingdom

Inbound travellers from Thailand, Spain, Italy and the United Kingdom must monitor their health for seven days prior to departure and record a "Personal Health Monitoring Form." Travellers transiting in Thailand must monitor for 14 days, while travellers from Indonesia must do so for a longer 21 day period and record a "Self-monitoring for Health Condition Form". The form must be printed out, completed and uploaded to the online Health Declaration Certificate to receive clearance for boarding China-bound flights.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Foreign nationals with inoculation certificates for COVID-19 vaccines produced in China have been exempted from submission requirements of negative COVID-19 nucleic acid test results, and Health and Travel Record Declaration Forms for visa applications when entering for work or family-related purposes from Hong Kong.

Only CoronaVac, BBIBP-CORV and WIBP-CORV vaccines are considered inactivated vaccines.

Foreign nationals with inoculation certificates for COVID-19 vaccines produced in China have been exempted from some document requirements, excluding certificates of negative COVID-19 tests, for visa applications for work or family-related purposes at Chinese embassies and consulates, including those in Belarus, Belgium, Denmark, Gabon, Germany, Hungary, India, Ireland, Italy, Israel, Japan, Norway, Pakistan, the Philippines, Slovakia, Spain, Sri Lanka, South Korea, Switzerland, Thailand, the United States, the United Kingdom, Vietnam and Russia.

Chinese-made COVID-19 vaccination certificates obtained outside of China must be notarised in Chinese and legalised. When vaccinated in Belarus, a vaccination certificate of a unified Belarusian format can be provided. Vaccination certificates obtained in Russia must comply with the unified Russian vaccination certificate format.

Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccine certificates have been accepted by the Chinese Embassies, but a negative IgM antibody test against N protein is still required for obtaining a QR code necessary for boarding China-bound flights.

Authorities announced in mid-February that heterologous booster shots will be allowed to people who have been fully vaccinated for at least six months; people can get a third shot of the same vaccine they previously used or a heterologous booster shot of Anhui Zhifei Longcom or CanSinoBIO.
qualifiedVaccines: IMBCAMS, China - 14 days after second dose.

areaPolicy.text: Social distancing measures apply in areas with no suspected COVID-19 cases ; however, in areas with suspected or confirmed cases, authorities have imposed strict movement restrictions and lockdown measures. Lockdown measures are in effect in Shanghai among other areas.

EG.summary: Cairo and Giza remain the worst-hit areas. Hundreds of new cases continue to be detected on a daily basis, but the situation remains largely stable and the healthcare system is coping relatively well. As of mid-May, less than 34 percent of the population was fully vaccinated.

areaRestrictions.text: A 19:00-06:00 local time curfew is in effect in North Sinai governorate in the areas east of Tel Rafah and along the borders with Israel and Gaza, as well as in Al-Awja west of Arish, due to insecurity. In Arish and some surrounding areas, the curfew is from 01:00-05:00 local time.
Domestic flights are operating. Public transport services are allowed to operate until 00:00 local time. Restaurants and cafes are allowed to operate until at least 02:00 local time.

Stores, malls, cafes, restaurants, parks and beaches are open.

Hotels are allowed to operate so long as they follow new health guidelines and operate at reduced capacity. The maximum capacity limit at hotels, restaurants, cinemas and theatres is at 70 percent.

transportation.text:
All airports have reopened.

EgyptAir resumed international flights to Europe, the United Kingdom (UK), Canada, the United States (US), Asia, Africa and the rest of the Middle East.

declarationDocuments.text:
Health Insurance document
Upon arrival, all foreign travellers must provide confirmation of having a valid health insurance policy.

Health document
All travellers must complete a monitoring card, which will be presented during the flight and is to be handed on arrival to health officials.

entry.text:
The border crossing with Rafah in Gaza is open.

To enter the country, travellers must either have valid proof of vaccination with a QR code or a negative PCR test. While fully vaccinated travellers are officially exempted from taking the pre-travel test, local sources indicate that they are still expected to have negative test results on arrival. Travellers from select countries are required to undergo a test upon arrival.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Officially, all unvaccinated travellers aged 12 and older, including Egyptian nationals, must present a negative PCR, ID NOW (NAAT) or antigen test result for COVID-19 no older than 72 hours.

Fully vaccinated travellers are officially exempted from taking the pre-travel test, but local sources indicate that they are still expected to have negative test results on arrival.

Only paper copies of the test results with a QR code are accepted.

Travellers from South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia and Eswatini are ineligible for pre-departure ID NOW (NAAT) testing and may only present pre-departure antigen or PCR test results no older than 72 hours

Only paper copies of the test results with a QR code are accepted.

Upon arrival

Travellers arriving from South Africa, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia or Zimbabwe must undergo an ID NOW PCR test upon arrival.

Any traveller testing positive for COVID-19 upon arrival is subject to a 10-day self-isolation, with the option of exiting quarantine on day six with a negative PCR test. If testing positive, travellers must undergo a second test before exiting quarantine.

Travellers entering the country from locations which have high instances of COVID-19 variants will be required to undergo an ID NOW (NAAT) test upon arrival; travellers testing positive will have to go into quarantine or be deported.

Any traveller testing positive for COVID-19 upon arrival is subject to a 10-day self-isolation, with the option of exiting quarantine on day six with a negative PCR test. If testing positive, travellers must undergo a second test before exiting quarantine.

Travellers whose test results and vaccine certificates are not registered by Egyptian authorities are subject to antigen testing upon arrival.

Any traveller testing positive for COVID-19 upon arrival is subject to a 10-day self-isolation, with the option of exiting quarantine on day six with a negative PCR test. If testing positive, travellers must undergo a second test before exiting quarantine.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text:
Travellers from South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia and Eswatini must self-quarantine for 14 days. A PCR test must be taken on day 7.

Unvaccinated tourists flying into South Sinai, the Red Sea and Matrouh governorates who are subject to testing on arrival are required to self-quarantine at their hotel until a result is obtained (usually within 24 hours). If testing positive, travellers will be required to self-isolate for 14 days in a separate part of the hotel allocated for quarantine.

mask.text: Face masks or coverings are mandatory in public; passengers will not be allowed to board vehicles unless they are masked.

otherRestriction.text: Upon arrival, all foreign travellers must provide confirmation of having a valid health insurance policy and complete a monitoring card.

diseaseVaccination.text: Travellers who were fully vaccinated at least 14 days prior to departure with COVID-19 vaccines approved by Egyptian authorities or the WHO are officially allowed to enter without a negative pre-departure test result for COVID-19, but local sources indicate that they are still expected to have negative test results on arrival. Only vaccination certificates including a QR code will be accepted by the Egyptian authorities.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sputnik V - 14 days after second dose.

areaPolicy.text: Some restrictions on movement and business operations remain in force until further notice.

ET.summary: Authorities previously implemented a state of emergency however this was lifted and few measures have remained in place due to ongoing, localised conflict and a fragile health system. Basic restrictions on gatherings and social distancing remain in place. As of early May, less than 19 percent of the country’s population is fully vaccinated.

areaRestrictions.text:
Amhara region

A 20:00-06:00 local time curfew is in effect until further notice, due to the ongoing offensive by the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF).

Public transport across the country is operating at a reduced capacity. Any person entering the Tigray region is required to quarantine for seven days unless they provide a negative COVID-19 PCR test no older than 24 hours.

Under the state of emergency imposed in Amhara region due to ongoing military conflict, internal checkpoints were established and security forces may confiscate private vehicles for military operations.

Meetings are allowed but all attendees must wear face masks. Sporting events have resumed, all attendees must be fully vaccinated or provide a negative rapid antigen test no older than 24 hours, or a negative PCR test no older than 72 hours.

Violators of COVID-19 restrictions are subject to fines between ETB 1,000-200,000 (USD 27-5,480).

transportation.text:
International flights are operational but multiple routes have been suspended due to travel restrictions. Further details on Ethiopian Airlines operations are available on the website https://www.ethiopianairlines.com/aa/travel-updates/updates-on-covid-19%28coronavirus%29.

Flights were suspended across the Tigray region due to the ongoing military conflict between Tigray People\'s Liberation Front (TPLF) rebels and military forces there.

entry.text: Travellers must be fully vaccinated or recovered to enter the country, nationals and diplomats are exempt but will be tested on arrival. Some overland border crossings are open with health screening measures in place.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

All arriving travellers are required to present a negative PCR test result that is no older than 72 hours or a rapid antigen test no older than 24 hours. Transit travellers are exempt. Diplomats and citizens are also exempt but will be required to undergo a rapid antigen test on arrival.

All travellers will be required to present a digitised test result as part of the African Union's Trusted Travel (TT) initiative or the UNDP's Global Haven system. Paper results will no longer be accepted.

Upon arrival

Diplomats and nationals are exempt from pre-departure testing or providing a vaccination certificate but will be tested at the airport upon entry. Should they test positive, they will need to self-isolate for 7 days.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

mask.text: Masks must be worn by people 5 years of age and older in public spaces. Violators face fines and up to three years imprisonment.

diseaseVaccination.text: Only individuals who have recovered from COVID-19 within the last 90 days and those with a vaccination certificate are allowed entry.
qualifiedVaccines: Vaxevria (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 7 days, not older than 3 months.

MG.summary: The country is suffering from a lack of oxygen, hospital beds and medical supplies, but a mass vaccination campaign is underway. Authorities lifted a state of emergency on 3 September 2021 after the epidemiological situation improved. As of early May, cases are decreasing while less than 4 percent of the population have been fully vaccinated.

areaRestrictions.text:
Inter-regional travel was allowed to resume in Analamanga, Vakinankaratra, Matsiatra Ambony and Anosy.

Public transport is operational.
Gatherings of more than 400 people are prohibited.

transportation.text:
Effective from 4 March through at least three months, flights to and from South Africa are banned.

All inbound passenger flights from Europe are operating; regional flights from Reunion are also operating.

declarationDocuments.text:
Health document
All travellers must present a commitment letter when boarding, vowing to self-isolate for a period of 24 to 48 hours until reception of their arrival PCR test result.

Travel (PLF) document
Travellers must complete a boarding form to present upon arrival.

Other document
A travel tracking form will be provided and required upon completion of the self-isolation period.

entry.text:
Borders have reopened to international travel from all countries.

Travellers must provide a negative PCR test no older than 72 hours before departure to be allowed entry.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers are required to present a negative PCR test dated within 72 hours of departure.

Upon arrival

Travellers are also required to take a rapid antigen test on arrival at Ivato International Airport, at their own expense, MGA65,000 (USD20).

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text: All travellers are required to undergo a rapid antigen test upon arrival and quarantine for up to 48 hours at an approved hotel until reception of their result. If the test result is positive, travellers must quarantine for seven days at an institutional facility and might also be required to undergo treatment.

mask.text: Masks must be worn in public spaces. Failure to do so may result in arrest.

otherRestriction.text: Cruise ships are permitted to dock into Nosy Be under the condition that travellers visit Nosy Be in one day. Travellers in cruise ships will also have been required to provide a negative PCR test to board their cruise ship.

diseaseVaccination.text: No information was available about the types of vaccines that are recognised by the local authorities.

areaPolicy.text: A nationwide health state of emergency was lifted on 3 September 2021. Minimal domestic measures remain in effect.

NG.summary: Vaccine access remains poor nationwide, with approximately 6 percent of the population fully vaccinated as of early May. COVID-19 related restrictions have periodically triggered violent unrest. A nightly curfew was strictly enforced throughout the country for 2 years before being lifted in April after the COVID-19 situation improved. Capacity restrictions on gatherings were also lifted, but a mask mandate remains in place, among other measures.

areaRestrictions.text:
A security-related 24-hour curfew in Jema'a and Kaura LGAs in Kaduna state until further notice.

A security-related dusk-to-dawn curfew is in place in Takum LGA and surrounding areas in Taraba state until further notice.
There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.

Most businesses have been allowed to resume operations at full capacity. Recreational venues, gyms and indoor sports facilities are operating at half capacity.

Social distancing and mask-wearing are required.

transportation.text: Commercial flight operations resumed through Lagos (LOS/DNMM), Abuja (ABV/DNAA), Kano (KAN/DNKN), Port Harcourt (PHC/DNPO) and Enugu (ENU/DNEN) airports.

declarationDocuments.text:
Travel (PLF) document
All arrivals must complete a health declaration and contact form to obtain a permit to travel certificate, which is to be submitted at the time of boarding their flight to Nigeria.

entry.text:
Most overland border crossings are closed; border crossings of Seme with Benin, Magatari and Illela with Niger and Mfum with Cameroon reopened.

Travellers must either provide valid proof of vaccination or a negative PCR test to enter the country.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

All unvaccinated travellers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result in English not older than 48 hours prior to boarding, obtained from an accredited laboratory as part of a pre-registration. Passengers must upload the test results to the Nigeria International Travel Portal and present documentary evidence of the negative test result prior to boarding. A QR code must also be presented upon arrival and it can be obtained at https://nitp.ncdc.gov.ng/onboarding/homepage

After arrival

All unvaccinated or partially vaccinated travellers entering Nigeria must self-quarantine for 7 days and take PCR tests on days 2 and 7 after arrival. Tests must be paid for in advance on the Nigeria International Travel Portal.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text:
All unvaccinated or partially vaccinated travellers must self-quarantine for seven days upon arrival and take PCR tests on days 2 and 7.

After seven days, those who test negative will be allowed to end their quarantine on the eighth day while those who test positive will be subject to further quarantine period for up to 14 days at a designated facility at their own expense.

mask.text: Masks are required in indoor public places and other high-risk areas. Masks are no longer required in outdoor settings.

exit.text: All outbound travellers are encouraged to be fully vaccinated and comply with testing requirements of their destination.

diseaseVaccination.text: All travellers who have been fully vaccinated are exempt from testing requirements quarantine on arrival.
qualifiedVaccines: Vaxevria (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sputnik V - 14 days after second dose.
Sputnik Light - 14 days after first dose.

areaPolicy.text: A countrywide nightly curfew was lifted but an indoor mask mandate remains in place, among other measures.
